episodeTitle: A Sudden Tragedy! A Gunshot Shuts Down the Future!
description: Queen Otohime returns with signatures from the World Nobles for her peace initiative. During the celebration, tragedy strikes when someone sets the petition boxes on fire and Otohime is shot. In her final moments, she asks her people not to hate the shooter, while her sons protect Shirahoshi from losing control of her emotions.

events.title: Shirahoshi's Power Revealed to Brothers
events.description: Queen Otohime explains to her sons Fukaboshi, Ryuboshi, and Manboshi that Shirahoshi is the legendary Mermaid Princess who can communicate with Sea Kings. She warns them that this power could either save or destroy the world if used incorrectly, and that Shirahoshi must be protected as she is unaware of her abilities.
events.significance: Establishes Shirahoshi as one of the Ancient Weapons (Poseidon) and explains why she must be protected. This is a critical reveal about Shirahoshi's role in the world's fate.

quotes.text: A Mermaid Princess of legend is capable of communicating with the Sea Kings. Shirahoshi is that princess.
quotes.speaker: Otohime
quotes.context: Otohime revealing Shirahoshi's secret power to her brothers

events.title: Brothers Vow to Protect Shirahoshi
events.description: After learning about Shirahoshi's dangerous power, Fukaboshi, Ryuboshi, and Manboshi all pledge to become strong warriors to protect their sister from those who would exploit her abilities.
events.significance: This vow drives the brothers' actions for the next ten years and explains their protective behavior towards Shirahoshi in the present timeline.

events.title: Vander Decken Learns of the Tamatebako
events.description: Vander Decken IX hears about the legendary Tamatebako treasure box and plans to obtain it. When his crew cannot retrieve it, he decides to wait several years until Shirahoshi grows older.
events.significance: Sets up Vander Decken's long-term obsession with Shirahoshi and his future use of the Tamatebako, which plays a crucial role in Big Mom's storyline.

events.title: Citizens Support Otohime's Dream
events.description: After Otohime returns with signatures from the World Nobles, the citizens of Fish-Man Island finally rally behind her cause. The celebration shows that her seven years of effort have paid off, with boxes overflowing with signatures supporting peaceful coexistence with humans.
events.significance: Represents the culmination of Otohime's life's work and shows that peaceful change seemed possible before the tragedy. Makes her death even more impactful.

quotes.text: All the citizens finally give her their signatures for her cause!
quotes.speaker: Narrator
quotes.context: Citizens of Fish-Man Island supporting Otohime's petition

events.title: Signature Boxes Set on Fire
events.description: At Gyoncorde Plaza, someone deliberately sets fire to the boxes containing the collected signatures. This creates chaos and confusion among the gathered crowd as they attempt to save the signatures representing years of Otohime's efforts.
events.significance: This arson attack creates the distraction that allows Hody Jones to assassinate Otohime. It destroys the physical evidence of the citizens' support for peace.

events.title: Queen Otohime Assassinated
events.description: During the chaos of the fire, Queen Otohime is shot by a hidden assassin. She collapses as her family and subjects rush to her side. The gunshot echoes through Gyoncorde Plaza, ending the hope for peaceful revolution.
events.significance: Otohime's assassination is one of the most pivotal moments in Fish-Man Island's history. Her death creates a generational trauma that affects the entire island and sets the stage for Hody Jones' rise to power. This is a defining moment that shapes the entire arc.

events.title: Vander Decken Marks Shirahoshi
events.description: Taking advantage of the chaos and Shirahoshi's shock, Vander Decken IX approaches the young princess and touches her with his right hand, marking her with his Mato Mato no Mi Devil Fruit power. This allows him to target her with thrown objects from any distance.
events.significance: This marking condemns Shirahoshi to ten years of imprisonment in the Hard-Shell Tower, as Decken constantly sends weapons and love letters toward her. It's the beginning of her captivity.

events.title: Otohime's Final Words: Do Not Hate
events.description: As she lays dying, Queen Otohime makes a final plea to her people and her children: do not hate the shooter or seek revenge. She asks them not to let her death spread more hatred through the island, emphasizing that she let her guard down because she was happy. She urges everyone to continue pursuing peace.
events.significance: Otohime's dying wish embodies her philosophy of peace and forgiveness. Her plea prevents immediate retaliation and demonstrates her unwavering commitment to her ideals even in death. This moment defines her legacy and influences how Fish-Man Island processes her assassination.

quotes.text: No matter who the perpetrator is, you mustn't allow yourselves to be enraged for my sake. Do not hate the shooter.
quotes.speaker: Otohime
quotes.context: Otohime's dying words to her children and people

events.title: Brothers Dance to Calm Shirahoshi
events.description: Remembering their mother's warning about Shirahoshi losing control of her emotions, Ryuboshi and Manboshi begin dancing and singing in front of the dying Otohime and shocked crowd. Their seemingly bizarre performance is actually a desperate attempt to keep Shirahoshi from crying and accidentally summoning the Sea Kings.
events.significance: This touching moment shows the brothers' dedication to protecting their sister and preventing catastrophe, even as their mother dies. It demonstrates the weight of responsibility placed on them and their immediate action to fulfill their vow.

quotes.text: We'll always watch over our sister!
quotes.speaker: Ryuboshi and Manboshi
quotes.context: The brothers dancing and singing to keep Shirahoshi from crying

events.title: Fukaboshi's Promise to Continue the Dream
events.description: Fukaboshi tearfully promises his dying mother that they will start over and keep her dream alive. He vows to protect Shirahoshi and continue working toward the peaceful coexistence with humans that Otohime dedicated her life to achieving.
events.significance: Fukaboshi's promise ensures that Otohime's dream doesn't die with her. This vow drives his actions for the next decade and sets up his leadership during the present-day crisis on Fish-Man Island.

quotes.text: We'll start over and keep your dream alive, so you don't have to worry. We'll protect Shirahoshi.
quotes.speaker: Fukaboshi
quotes.context: Fukaboshi's tearful promise to his dying mother

events.title: Otohime's Death - Final Pinky Promise
events.description: In her final moments, Queen Otohime and her four children touch pinky fingers one last time, a gesture symbolizing their bond and the promises made. Surrounded by her family, Otohime passes away peacefully, having heard her son's vow to continue her dream.
events.significance: This emotional farewell marks the end of Otohime's life and the beginning of a new era for Fish-Man Island. The pinky finger gesture becomes a powerful symbol of the family's bond and their commitment to her ideals.

quotes.context: Revealing Shirahoshi's power to her brothers

themes.description: Otohime's dying wish for her people not to hate the assassin embodies the episode's central theme of breaking the cycle of hatred through forgiveness.
themes.symbolism: The burning signatures represent how easily progress toward peace can be destroyed, while Otohime's final words represent the enduring power of her ideals.
culturalReferences: Martin Luther King Jr.'s philosophy of non-violence

themes.description: Otohime dedicates her life to peace between humans and fish-men, and even in death, she sacrifices personal vengeance for the sake of her dream.
themes.symbolism: The pinky finger gesture symbolizes the unbreakable bond between Otohime and her children, and the promise that transcends death.

themes.theme: The Cycle of Hatred and Discrimination
themes.description: The episode explores how violence and prejudice perpetuate themselves, and how one person's death can either fuel more hatred or inspire change.
themes.symbolism: The fire destroying the signatures represents how easily hatred can consume progress toward understanding.

themes.description: The brothers' immediate action to protect Shirahoshi, even as their mother dies, demonstrates the strength of family bonds and duty.
themes.symbolism: Ryuboshi and Manboshi's dance represents the lengths family will go to protect one another.

characterSpotlights.development: Otohime's character arc concludes with her assassination. Her final words cement her legacy as a martyr for peace, demonstrating that her commitment to forgiveness and understanding persists even in death.

characterSpotlights.development: Fukaboshi transitions from prince to the heir who must carry on his mother's dream. His promise to Otohime marks his evolution into a leader who will guide Fish-Man Island for the next decade.

characterSpotlights.development: Young Shirahoshi is marked by Vander Decken and traumatized by her mother's death in the same moment, setting up her decade-long imprisonment and emotional struggles.
keyActions: Nearly loses control of her emotions

characterSpotlights.development: Vander Decken takes advantage of the tragedy to mark Shirahoshi, beginning his ten-year campaign of harassment that imprisons the princess.

Marks Shirahoshi with Mato Mato no Mi during the chaos

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime extended scenes of Fish-Man Island citizens giving Otohime their signatures, showing more of the celebration and community support.
The anime added additional reaction shots of the crowd during Otohime's assassination and final words.

trivia.fact: This episode adapts manga chapters 625 (pages 18-19) and 626 (pages 2-19), covering one and a half chapters.
The episode aired on May 6, 2012 in Japan, during the height of the Fish-Man Island arc's exploration of discrimination and prejudice themes.
Queen Otohime's assassination is considered one of the most emotionally impactful deaths in One Piece, often compared to other tragic backstory deaths like Dr. Hiriluk and Bellemere.
The opening song 'We Go!' by Hiroshi Kitadani was used from episodes 517-590, making it one of the longer-running openings in the series.
Michiko Neya, who voices Otohime in Japanese, is known for voicing strong female characters in anime.
